admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts were only modest. Lessons stress the following. The
            simplified formula by which civil works contractors
            subcontracted the equipment, supervised by a consultant
            project manager, proved efficient, with limited management
            requirements, and expenses at the Civil Aviation and
            Meteorological Authority (CAM). However, procurement
            problems plagued this project from the beginning, causing
            major delays, despite procurement workshops during the
            project launch. To this end, it is suggested to engage a
            full time procurement specialist in the implementing agency.
            Although project design, and performance indicators
            rightfully addressed sector management issues, these were
            not fully focused on quantitative objectives for
            revenue-generation, neither towards achieving efficient, and
            effective management, both issues closely related. However,
            through the technical assistance to the Yemeni Board for the
            Management of the Road Maintenance Fund, the project
            established the analytical capacity to implement planning,
            programming, and budgeting exercises, which can provide the
            framework for discussions on network priorities. Other
            lessons address the importance of maintaining dialogues on
            institutional goals, and, the need for civil service reform
            should be pursued (i.e., linked to the Civil Service
            Modernization Project).
